laws.summary: New Jersey restricts non-compete agreements through case law. Non-competes must protect legitimate business interests and be reasonable in scope, duration (typically 1 year), and geography. Courts carefully scrutinize non-competes and will not enforce overly broad agreements. New Jersey is generally employee-friendly on non-competes.
laws.statute_citation: Common law; Solari Industries v. Malady, 55 N.J. 571 (1970) and subsequent case law
requirements: Must protect legitimate business interest (trade secrets, confidential information, specialized training)
Must be reasonable in temporal scope (typically maximum 1 year)
Must be reasonable in geographic scope (limited to area of actual competition)
Must be reasonable in scope of prohibited activities
Must be supported by adequate consideration
Cannot be oppressive or unduly burdensome on employee
Must not harm public interest
Courts apply three-part test: protects legitimate interest, reasonable, not harmful to public
New Jersey courts strictly construe non-competes against employers
Courts generally will NOT blue-pencil unreasonable provisions
Lower-level employees rarely subject to enforceable non-competes
Trend toward narrower enforcement in recent years
laws.notes: New Jersey is employee-friendly on non-competes. Courts scrutinize carefully and require strong justification. Federal FTC ban blocked in 2024.

laws.summary: New Jersey prohibits employers from asking about salary history. Employers cannot screen applicants based on salary history, ask about prior compensation, or use salary history in setting compensation. One of the strongest salary history bans in the country.
laws.statute_citation: N.J.S.A. 34:11-5.12 et seq. (Diane B. Allen Equal Pay Act)
requirements: Employers cannot ask about applicant's salary history
Cannot screen applicants based on salary history
Cannot require salary history disclosure
Cannot use prior salary history to set compensation
Cannot search public records for salary history
Applicant may voluntarily disclose salary history without prompting
If voluntarily disclosed, employer may consider but cannot rely solely on it
Applies to all New Jersey employers
Employers must post notice of employees' right to equal pay
Violations can result in civil penalties and damages
Effective January 1, 2020
laws.notes: New Jersey has one of the strongest salary history bans. Part of comprehensive equal pay legislation.

laws.summary: New Jersey does NOT currently require salary ranges in job postings. However, under the Diane B. Allen Equal Pay Act, employers must provide pay range information to employees who are promoted or transferred, and to employees upon request for their current position. No general posting requirement exists.
laws.statute_citation: N.J.S.A. 34:11-5.12 (Diane B. Allen Equal Pay Act)
requirements: Must provide pay range to employees upon request for their current position
Must provide pay range for position when promoting or transferring employee
NOT required to include salary ranges in external job postings
Employees have right to discuss wages without retaliation
Employers cannot prohibit employees from discussing compensation
Violations can result in civil penalties
Applies to all New Jersey employers
laws.notes: New Jersey has limited pay transparency requirements focused on current employees, not job postings.

laws.summary: New Jersey has comprehensive 'ban the box' law (Fair Chance in Housing Act and Opportunity to Compete Act). Employers cannot ask about criminal history on initial applications. Cannot inquire about criminal history until after first interview. Strict limitations on what can be asked and considered.
laws.statute_citation: N.J.S.A. 34:6B-14 (Opportunity to Compete Act); N.J.S.A. 2A:168A-1 (Fair Chance in Housing Act)
requirements: Cannot ask about criminal history on initial application
Cannot inquire about criminal history until after FIRST INTERVIEW
Cannot ask about: arrests not resulting in conviction, participation in diversion/treatment programs, expunged/sealed records
After conditional offer: may conduct background check
Must provide applicant with copy of background check
Must conduct individualized assessment if taking adverse action
Must consider: nature of offense, time elapsed, job duties, rehabilitation
Must provide written notice of adverse action with opportunity to respond
Cannot automatically disqualify based on criminal record
Exceptions: positions where law prohibits hiring people with certain records
Applies to employers with 15+ employees (later expanded to all employers)
Violations enforced by Attorney General - civil penalties up to $5,000 first offense, $10,000 subsequent
laws.notes: New Jersey has one of strongest ban-the-box laws. Cannot ask about criminal history until after first interview.

laws.summary: New Jersey requires employers to provide earned sick leave. Employees accrue 1 hour of paid sick leave for every 30 hours worked, up to 40 hours per year. Applies to all employers regardless of size.
laws.statute_citation: N.J.S.A. 34:11D-1 et seq. (New Jersey Earned Sick Leave Law)
requirements: Applies to ALL New Jersey employers (no size threshold)
Employees accrue 1 hour per 30 hours worked
Maximum 40 hours per year
Can begin using after 120th calendar day of employment
Employers may cap accrual at 40 hours
Must allow carryover of unused time year-to-year
May cap usage at 40 hours per year
Use allowed for: employee illness/injury, family member care, medical appointments, domestic/sexual violence situations, school closures for public health emergency
Can use for child's school-related conferences, meetings, events
Employers may require up to 7 days advance notice for foreseeable absences
NOT required to pay out unused sick leave at termination
Must provide written notice of sick leave rights
Records must be maintained for 5 years
Violations: civil penalties, retaliation prohibited
Effective October 29, 2018
laws.notes: New Jersey earned sick leave applies to ALL employers with no size exemption. One of more comprehensive state sick leave laws.

laws.summary: New Jersey enforces arbitration agreements but with some restrictions. Follows Federal Arbitration Act generally. Courts scrutinize arbitration agreements for unconscionability more closely than many states. Must be fair, mutual, and not waive substantive rights.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Arbitration Act (9 U.S.C. §§ 1-16); New Jersey common law
requirements: Arbitration agreements generally enforceable under FAA
Must be in writing and clearly presented
Must have mutual agreement to arbitrate
Must identify claims subject to arbitration
Cannot be procedurally or substantively unconscionable
Must allow meaningful opportunity to review before signing
Cannot impose unreasonable costs on employee
Must provide for neutral arbitrator
Adequate consideration required
New Jersey courts scrutinize arbitration agreements more carefully than many states
Class action waivers generally enforceable but subject to challenge
Pre-dispute arbitration agreements enforceable if fair
Can be challenged on unconscionability grounds
laws.effective_date: Ongoing under federal and state law
laws.notes: New Jersey courts more willing to find arbitration agreements unconscionable than some states. Must be procedurally fair.

laws.summary: New Jersey follows at-will employment doctrine with significant exceptions. Either party can terminate employment, but New Jersey recognizes broader exceptions than many states including implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing in some contexts.
laws.statute_citation: Common law doctrine; N.J.S.A. 10:5-1 et seq. (New Jersey Law Against Discrimination - NJLAD)
requirements: Default: Employment terminable at will by either party
No notice required unless contract/policy requires it
Final wages must be paid by next regular payday

EXCEPTIONS - Cannot terminate for: Race, creed, color, national origin, ancestry, age, marital status, civil union status, domestic partnership status, affectional/sexual orientation, gender identity/expression, sex, pregnancy, disability, atypical hereditary cellular/blood trait, genetic information, military service (NJLAD - very broad)
Cannot terminate for: Retaliation (whistleblowing, workers' comp, jury duty, military service)
Cannot terminate for: Violation of public policy (Pierce v. Ortho - refusing to violate professional ethics)
Cannot terminate for: Breach of employment contract or handbook provisions
Employment handbooks create enforceable obligations if not properly disclaimed
New Jersey recognizes implied covenant of good faith in certain long-term employment relationships
Written employment contracts override at-will status
Union/collective bargaining agreements override at-will status
New Jersey is more employee-friendly than many states on wrongful termination
laws.notes: New Jersey has stronger employee protections than many at-will states. NJLAD is one of broadest anti-discrimination laws. Handbook disclaimers critical.

laws.summary: New Jersey prohibits employment discrimination against cannabis users under the Cannabis Regulatory, Enforcement Assistance, and Marketplace Modernization Act (CREAMMA). Employers cannot take adverse action based solely on cannabis use outside work hours. Complex testing requirements with Workplace Impairment Recognition Expert (WIRE) procedures.
requirements: Cannot discriminate against employees for cannabis use outside work hours
Cannot refuse to hire applicants solely based on positive cannabis test
Pre-employment testing permitted but cannot be sole basis for hiring decision
To take action for suspected workplace impairment: must use scientifically valid drug test
If positive for cannabinoids: must use Workplace Impairment Recognition Expert (WIRE) for physical evaluation
WIRE must conduct standardized evaluation to determine actual impairment
Can test for: reasonable suspicion of workplace use, observable signs of impairment, regular screening during work hours, random testing for safety-sensitive positions, post-accident investigation
Must have written drug testing policy
Cannot test based solely on smell of cannabis
Positive test + lack of physical impairment signs = cannot take adverse action
Safety-sensitive positions may have additional testing latitude
Federal contractors must comply with federal drug-free workplace requirements
Complex compliance - consultation with employment counsel recommended
laws.notes: New Jersey has most complex cannabis workplace protections in country. WIRE requirement creates significant compliance obligations. Employers cannot rely solely on positive drug test.

data_quality.sources: New Jersey statutes (N.J.S.A.), New Jersey Department of Labor, Cannabis Regulatory Commission guidance, legal analysis

additional_notes.general_guidance: New Jersey is very employee-friendly with comprehensive worker protections. Strong anti-discrimination law (NJLAD), ban-the-box, salary history ban, earned sick leave, and cannabis protections create significant compliance requirements.
enforcement_agencies: New Jersey Department of Labor and Workforce Development
New Jersey Division on Civil Rights
recent_developments: Cannabis workplace protections effective 2021 - ongoing complexity
Cannabis Regulatory Commission released interim drug testing guidance 2022-2023
NJLAD expanded to include additional protected classes
Strong salary history ban effective since 2020
